lines.text: I'm a very important person, with all kinds of important secrets. Listen, and I will tell you one... my wife is very beautiful.
More beautiful than I?
Hers is a quiet kind of beauty, soft and warm.
And mine?
Your beauty is a thing carved out of granite, with no body or soul.
I've got some news for you.
News, news, news. The world of full of news these days.
Oh, this is something I...
Don't get excited about it. That's very important. And don't get believe everything you hear.
This just came from Moscow.
Ah, then you must believe it, every word of it.
Listen, Comrade Major. Our wives are arriving, day after tomorrow.
Oh, no! What time?
Eleven thirty.
If we're lucky, the train will be late, very late.
Comrade Major, my wife will be on that train.
Your wife was never a captain in the Red Army!

There must be no misconception about our relations with our former capitalist allies. Our interests can never coincide. Our rules and aims are quite different. We have no place for bourgeois sentimentalism, only relentless realism. The class struggle will continue, until this decadent, plutocratic democracy is as completely destroyed as National Socialism. Therefore, you, the representatives of the Soviet Union in Canada, will as always remain vigilant, suspicious, and aloof. That will be all.
That fantastic mushroom over Hiroshima. I saw the newsreel pictures. I can't get them out of my head.
A beautiful, poisonous mushroom.
I've got blood on both hands, and I sleep with dead faces on my eyeballs.
As a man, I'm called a sadist, but what of governments that pile dead upon dead and justify murder as a means to an end?
An efficient firing squad will solve all my problems. Takes too long to drink oneself to death.
Truth? What's that? I used to know when I was a very little boy.
Don't be too unhappy, Leitz. We'll name a city after you, when we take over.
